items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
On Tuesday, August 28, 2012, the District’s Maintenance Supervisor communicated with the District Office that two of the three chillers that comprise San Jose City College’s (SJCC) Chiller System required major repairs due to leaks. Normally, SJCC runs on two chillers, with one as a backup for maintenance issues or all three to run concurrently on especially hot days. After the discovery of the leaks, SJCC had to run on one chiller to cool the entire campus. In so doing, this single chiller was overloaded with the VSD drive constantly tripping. To temporarily remedy this issue, maintenance staff had to constantly reset said tripping mechanism twice daily, once in the afternoon, and again in the morning. Moreover, the Fall semester was set to begin on Tuesday, September 4, 2012.
	 
With only one chiller online, this crippled system could not support classrooms and the campus as a whole running at full capacity. Furthermore, with SJCC's new Multi-Disciplinary Arts Building set to open for the Fall 2012 semester, this building is also connected to SJCC’s Chiller System, making the demand for air conditioned air even greater than the prior year. Having just one functional chiller, with it constantly being reset due to it being overloaded is a health and safety concern for our students, staff and faculty, as well as potential damage and danger to the District’s property.
	 
To quickly and safely remedy this issue, the District sought the attached three informal bids. If the District were to seek formal bids, it will further delay SJCC to have a fully functioning Chiller System running at full capacity, that is, when considering the first day of school quickly approaching, as well as continue to expose students, staff, faculty and the District to dangers of life and property. Consequently, the District invoked California Public Contract Code Section 20654, whereby it states that “In an emergency when any repairs, alterations, work or improvements is necessary to a facility of the college, or to permit the continuance of existing college classes, or to avoid danger to life or property, the board may by unanimous vote, with the approval of the county superintendent of schools … make a contract in writing or otherwise on behalf of the district for the performance of labor and furnishing of materials or supplies for the purpose without advertising for or inviting bids.” The District received approval from Dr. Xavier De La Torre, Santa Clara County Superintendent of Schools.
	 
Therefore, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees unanimously approve and award the contract to ACCO Engineered Systems in the amount of $38,860.00 for the emergency repair of Chiller #1 and Chiller #2 at San Jose City College “without advertising for or inviting bids” “to avoid the danger of life or property.”
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the emergency contract with ACCO Engineered Systems for the emergency repair of Chiller #1 and Chiller #2 at San Jose City College.

The Silicon Valley Stepping Stones Grant partnership was funded by the California Community College Systemâs Office, Career Technical Education Community Collaborative Programs, with the West Valley-Mission Community College District acting as the fiscal agent. EVC participates in this regional partnership of educational institutions in Silicon Valley to expand articulation efforts. This agenda item includes the continuation of two MOUs. The first MOU, effective July 1, 2011 through December 31, 2012, includes funding in the amount of $22,501. If this MOU is not approved, EVC will lose $22,501 in grant funding. The second MOU, effective July 1, 2012 through December 31, 2013, includes funding in the amount of $19,576. Each MOU allows the college to receive funds to conduct activities identified in the MOU.
Funding is contingent upon SB 70 funding from the State of California and the WVCCD receiving advanced apportionment from the State of California.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve continuation of the MOUs and accept grant funding in the amount of $22,501 and $19,576 from the West Valley-Mission Community College District (WVCCD).

items.item_details:
The approved Today in America video segment of SJECCD is being shown at this board meeting as a recognition and celebration of the collective work done by students, faculty, staff and administrators to "produce" an abundance of successful student stories. It reminds us of why so many of us have chosen to work in the community college system--to be a part of the important work in higher education that advances the educational and economic success of our local communities. 
	 
Today in America is a unique show hosted by Terry Bradshaw that's geared toward an "educated and affluent" audience.  The Show covers the best new practices and stories of various industries and has won numerous industry awards.  Late last year, the Show contacted SJECCD after strong recommendation by the President of AACC (American Association of Community Colleges) to select our District to be showcased for its workforce leadership, particularly in programs like nursing, cosmetology, and the Workforce Institute's workforce development solutions for the greater San Jose area.  
	 
After our selection by the Today in America Show, a team of students, faculty, staff, administrators and show producers worked together for 9+ months to produce the SJECCD "story" for viewing markets in the US. 
	 
The SJECCD segment on the Today in America Show will air nationally and regionally over several months and in up to 15 different television markets.  Notification of airing stations, times and dates is provided on a month-to-month basis as networks provide details.
